w:r.w:t: In Tutorial 5 exercise 5 we created a two-way communication channel to send data from the client to the server in the body of a POST request and have the server issue a response including data.

we can instantiate an object at one end, encode its fields in JSON format, send it to the other end via a POST request or response and instantiate and initialize an identical object at the other end. Google luckily make a very easy to use library called GSON for encoding objects into JSON strings.
Add a line in the dependencies section of
for both the client and the server as follows, to include the
(remember to refresh the Gradle task window)
Add a Patient class to both your client and servlet – it should have fields such as name, id,
of class Patient and initialize its fields with some example values.
is now a text representation of the fields in p and their values – have a look at it, or
it to the console to see how JSON encodes the fields and their values. Send this to the servlet instead of the Hello Servlet message of Tut5 Ex5.
Run the servlet and the client –
the servlet should now have created an object of class Patient which has

field values as the object in the client. Ie we can now send objects from the client to the servlet, and by doing something similar with the response, we can send objects back to the client from the servlet. If you are putting JSON in the response body, make sure to set the appropriate response content type to indicate that the body is

w:r.w:t: Install a Postgres database locally on your machine
(write down or remember the password you use when setting it up)
Open IntelliJ and select View->Tool Windows->Database
In the database window, click the plus button and add a data source of type PostgreSQL and use the following values
Click Test Connection and it should be successful. Click OK and in the database window you should see your database connection tree.
Click the QL icon at the top of the database window->New Console

We can now enter SQL (Structured Query Language) commands in the main console that has appeared. SQL is the common language of databases, although there are slightly different dialects depending on the specific database. We are using the Postgres dialect.

We will create a new table in the database that stores patient information. A table is like a spreadsheet which has columns for different fields, and the rows contains the values for each patient. Enter the following SQL in the console window and then click the go button (play button top left of console window
This creates an empty table called patients with four columns – id,
. Each row inserted into the table represents these values for each patient.

is declared as type SERIAL, which means an auto-incrementing 4-byte integer, and is a PRIMARY KEY – which means that it is used to uniquely identify each row in the table – no two rows can have the same id even if all other columns are the same. There can’t be more than one primary key column in a table. We don’t have to set this column explicitly – it will be set by Postgres when we add the other fields.

128) which means that they are strings of chars with a maximum length defined as 128 chars. The number of chars is our decision. They are both declared NOT NULL, which means that these fields must have a value and can’t be left blank.
is a string of maximum 32 chars which is optional and can be left blank –
NULL because it is not declared as NOT NULL.
Other useful column types in Postgres
We will now insert a row into the table – enter the following in the console and click
Try inserting a few more patients
Now in the View->Tool Windows->Database you should see something like the

w:r.w:t: We are now going to do a role play with your program and Git for a very common scenario. Create an app that prints ‘Hello, World!’ to the console, and create a remote repo (VCS->Share Project on
). This creates a single branch called the master branch and pushes it to
(you can see this indicated in the bottom right hand corner of IntelliJ). Tag this as v1.0 (Git->Tag) and push to
again (making sure to check ‘Push tags’ on the push window)
The role play action will take place as follows:
v1.0 has been shipped to the
, and they are getting good sales and are very pleased with the way it displays Hello,
You are to start work on an update called v1.1, and the customer has provided three user requirements – read them and then start on step 1
The program should continue to print “Hello, World” as before
It should also print the integers between 1 and 10 inclusive, (note
can take an integer as a parameter) then
calculate and print the sum of all integers from 30 to 40.
a branch on which to develop the new version
Git->Branches->New Branch. This will also change your local repo so that any work you now do is on the new branch. The currently active branch is shown in the bottom right corner of IntelliJ.
Start work on ver1.1, and complete requirement B, compile and run your code to check it.

However – the customer has just phoned and it’s an emergency! Their competitor’s program prints “Good Morning, Universe!” instead of “Hello, World!” and this program should do the same immediately – this requires a quick turnaround so that the competitor doesn’t take their customers!
As you are halfway through v1.1, you haven’t got time to complete it, test it and train the customer with the new functionality - you need to make a quick update to the previous code of v1.0.
Add, commit and push the changes that you have made so far to branch v1.1_devel. If you check on
you will see that the new branch exists.
Switch back to the master branch (Git->Branches->master->checkout, or the same from the indicator at the bottom right of
). You should now see the previous version of the .java file in your editor.
Change the message to Good Morning, Universe!
Build and run to test it.
Commit the changes, tag it as v1.0-ud1 and then push the new code and the tag. (If the Git menu doesn’t appear, click VCS->Integrate with Source Control)
v1.1_devel->Checkout, and finish user requirement C. Build it, check it works, commit and push it.
You have now finished development of v1.1 and must merge v1.1 back into the
should also include the changes made in update 1. To do so, switch back to the master branch and then merge the v1.1 branch with Git->Branches->v1.1_devel->Merge
both branches you will be prompted to

choose from three options – choose the master version, or choose the v1.1_devel version, or manage the code merge. You will do the latter - click the merge button. You will get a merge dialog box – the two versions on each side, and the middle box for the required outcome. F
between the two different versions (there are >> buttons to choose the code from each side).
Build and test your program, then commit it, then tag it v1.1.
Now – if you want - you can delete the v1.1_devel branch, or you can keep it in case you need to go back to it at a later stage. Then push to

w:r.w:t: Get together with a course-mate and try some of the following exercise – make sure you understand what is going on.
that one of you created for the previous exercise – you can add a collaborator from
The customer has the following requirements for
The program must do what it already did in v1.1.
The program must then print the factorials of integers from 1 to 5.
print 1.4 to the power n for integer n from 1 to 5.
on their machine (you can open a cloned repo in IntelliJ as a project
You are going to split the work between you. Each create different branches that aren’t the master to work on – one of you code 2b., and the other code 2c. and 2d on your separate branches.
When your tasks are finished – don’t merge with the master locally but push your working branch to
You each want your changes to be approved by the other and accepted into the
Pull Request tab, create a New Pull Request from your branch into the master –
You can add a message with the request, and
will email your collaborator, informing them of the request.
The other collaborator can now view the pull request, which will be visible from the
‘Pull Request’ tab. They can approve the request and merge the code into the master branch from
The collaborator who approved the change can then Pull the new version of the master branch to their local repo.
